Suggestion: I don't know if you already did something about the problem with CLFLVSplitter.ax and Windows Media Player. Basically CLFLVSplitter.ax cause a crash when you play flv videos in Windows Media Player. The solution is to unregister it (regsvr32 /u CLFLVSplitter.ax). 

This problem doesn't happen to all users, but you can add a batch file to a future version of your pack, just for users that experience the problem.

You're welcome! :)

@ masterfaster2: Thanks, I'll add it to the next release!

@ butt2butt: It's a known problem,.. they are working on it.

@ Moamma: I experienced the same problem.

I've created a fix,.. it works on my system and I hope it also works on yours.

Create a new text document and copy and paste the lines below:


Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Cyberlink\PowerDVD10]
"UIFocusCDDrive"=dword:00000008
"UIFocusPrevDrive"=dword:00000006


Save the file as FocusDriveFix.reg and merge it.

PowerDVD will ask the question one more time and now it should save it.

Cheers,

ADHDerby

@ Moamma: Try a clean re-install:
1) Uninstall PowerDVD and reboot.
2) Create a new text document and copy and paste the lines below:


Windows Registry Editor Version 5.00

[-HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\CyberLink\PowerDVD10]

[-HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Cyberlink\PowerDVD10]


Save the file as CleanupPDVD.reg and merge it.
This will remove the PowerDVD settings from the registry.

3) Re-install PowerDVD.

@ jobinmathew: They are probably not ripped correctly.
Guide for unprotected Blu-ray ISO for PowerDVD: http://forum.slysoft.com/showthread.php?t=24169
Most of the time you can fix the image by checking the folder structure and adding the missing folders.

Just have a question.  I tend to get Blu-Ray DVD torrents, and they download in a MP4 format.  I don't have a Blu-Ray DVD player, and my current DVD player wont play MP4 formats.  But I do have the 42" 1080 HDTV connected to my PC via HDMI!  In the past I tend to play movies with VLC player, and watch it on my 42" 1080 HDTV via the HDMI channel.

So if I use PowerDVD 10 as my "Blu-Ray DVD player", and have the HDMI channel on the TV turnt on, will I still get Blu-Ray quality on my 42" 1080 HDTV, even though the file is being played via PowerDVD on my PC.

Hope that makes sense...

to the users who have problems with their audio, its because more than likely you do NOT have HD audio output with surround sound encoding available. Meaning, your sound card probably doesnt have a surround output at all. also, to those who have problems with the seek bar, try to update your computer. include both the windows updates and PowerDVD updates. their might be an issue with your specific computer that prevents it from working properly. if it breaks the activation, simply reapply it. as long as the executable is not the one being patched, then the versions should not mismatch and the patch should be fine in any version. lets hope that ADHDerby was able to accomplish this. :)
